pr_title: Refactor out common test classes into new test project

timeline.bodyText:
I don't know how this project will be used, but will source files in this project need using classes from jib-plugins-common and jib-core?
What's weird to me is that jib-core depends on jib-testing-common (albeit via testImplementation) but jib-testing-common depends on jib-core.
timeline.author: chanseokoh
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,16 @@
+plugins {
+  id 'java'
+}
+
+// disable javadoc on this project, it's only for testing
+tasks.javadoc.enabled = false
+
+dependencies {
+  // if you want to use classes that have dependencies in the main source
+  // sets of other projects, mark them compile only
+  compileOnly project(':jib-plugins-common')
+  compileOnly project(':jib-core')

replies.bodyText: jib-core:test can be seen as it's own project with a dependency on jib-core. Since the common testing infrastructure is bound to reference production classes, I think this is necessary. But if the question is: Is this PR necessary? I think it's convenient.
replies.author: loosebazooka

timeline.bodyText:
nit: for consistency, testImplementation project(':jib-testing-common') (without specifying the path argument name).
And does the order of testImplementation matter? In jib-core, it's the first entry.
